2. Commencement; This Act comes into ope.a: sections 1 and 2  on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent
2. Commencement; This Act comes into ope.b: the rest of the Act  on a day fixed by proclamation, and different days may be fixed for different provisions.

3. Terms used in this Act.In this Act, unless the contrary intenti: surrogacy arrangement means an arrangement for a woman (the birth mother ) to seek to become pregnant and give birth to a child and for a person or persons other than the birth mother (the arranged parent or arranged parents ) to raise the child, but the term does not include an arrangement entered into after the birth mother becomes pregnant unless it is in variation of a surrogacy arrangement involving the same parties.

Division 1 General.4. What this Part is about: This Part deals with the status of surrogacy arrangements and prohibits certain surrogacy arrangements and certain things to do with surrogacy arrangements.

5. Term used in this Part.In this Part, unless the contrary intent: surrogacy arrangement that is for reward has the meaning given in section 6.

(1) This Part refers to a surrogacy arra.a: the pregnancy or the birth or
(1) This Part refers to a surrogacy arra.b: any assessment or expert advice in connection with the arrangement.

6. Meaning of surrogacy arrangement that.(2): Reasonable expenses associated with achieving, or attempting to achieve, the pregnancy are reasonable expenses associated with the pregnancy.

(3) An expense is a reasonable expense f.a: a reasonable medical expense that is not recoverable under any health insurance or other scheme or
(3) An expense is a reasonable expense f.c: a reasonable expense of psychological counselling or

(d) a premium payable for health, disabi.(i) would not have been taken out if the: (ii) provides cover for a period during which an expense referred to in another paragraph of this subsection is incurred or might be, or have been expected to be, incurred.

7. Surrogacy arrangement not binding.(1): A surrogacy arrangement is not enforceable except to the extent provided for in subsection (3).
7. Surrogacy arrangement not binding.(2): Subsection (1) does not affect the ability of the court to make an order under Part 3.
7. Surrogacy arrangement not binding.(3): An obligation under a surrogacy arrangement to pay or reimburse reasonable expenses referred to in section 6(1) is as enforceable as it would be if subsection (1) had not been enacted and the arrangement was not unenforceable for any other reason.

8. Making surrogacy arrangement that is.content1: A person who enters into a surrogacy arrangement that is for reward commits an offence.
8. Making surrogacy arrangement that is.content2: Penalty a fine of $24 000 or imprisonment for 2 years.

9. Reward for introducing parties for su.(1): A person who receives, or seeks to receive, valuable consideration for introducing or agreeing to introduce persons
9. Reward for introducing parties for su.(2): Subsection (1) applies whether or not it is intended that the surrogacy arrangement be one that is for reward.

A person commits an offence if the perso.a: anything that is intended to, or likely to, induce a person to enter into a surrogacy arrangement that is for reward or
A person commits an offence if the perso.b: anything to the effect that a person who is willing to enter into a surrogacy arrangement that is for reward is sought or
A person commits an offence if the perso.c: anything to the effect that a person is or might be willing to enter into a surrogacy arrangement that is for reward.

11. Services connected with surrogacy ar.(1): A person who provides a service knowing that the service is to facilitate a surrogacy arrangement that is for reward commits a crime except in the circumstances described in subsection (2).

(2) It is not an offence against subsect.content2: Summary conviction penalty a fine of $12 000 or imprisonment for one year.

Division 1 Preliminary.12. What this Part is about: This Part is to enable the court to transfer, from the birth parents to the arranged parents, the parentage of a child born under a surrogacy arrangement in certain circumstances.

13. Childs best interests paramount.(1): In deciding whether to make a particular decision concerning a parentage order or proposed parentage order about a child, the court must regard the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration.
13. Childs best interests paramount.(2): For the purposes of this Act it is presumed to be in the best interests of the child for the arranged parents to be the parents of the child, unless there is evidence to the contrary.

14. Terms used in this Part; In this Par.content1: approved plan means the plan that section 21(2)(f) refers to by that term, as varied, if applicable, with the courts approval under section 30

arranged parents of a child means.a: the persons who, according to the definition of surrogacy arrangement in section 3, are the arranged parents or
arranged parents of a child means.b: the person who, according to that definition, is the arranged parent

birth parents of a child means.a: the persons who are recognised by the law as being, when the child is born, the parents of the child or
birth parents of a child means.b: if only one person fits the description in paragraph (a), that person

14. Terms used in this Part; In this Par.content4: chief executive officer means the chief executive officer of the department of the Public Service principally assisting the Minister in the administration of this Act
14. Terms used in this Part; In this Par.content5: child refers to the status of a person in a relationship as parent and child, and it includes a person of that status even after the person has reached the age of full legal capacity
14. Terms used in this Part; In this Par.content6: court means the Family Court of Western Australia

independent legal advice is legal advice.a: is chosen by the person receiving the advice and
independent legal advice is legal advice.b: is not providing advice to the arranged parents as well as to any other person required to receive the advice

14. Terms used in this Part; In this Par.content8: parentage order means an order that the court makes under this Part transferring the parentage of a child.

15. Meaning of Council.In this Division: Council means the Western Australian Reproductive Technology Council established under the  Human Reproductive Technology Act 1991 section 8.

16. Approval of surrogacy arrangement.(1): A parentage order cannot be made in respect of a child unless the surrogacy arrangement has been approved in writing under section 17 by the Council.
16. Approval of surrogacy arrangement.(2): Subsection (1) does not apply if the child was born as a result of a pregnancy that commenced before the day fixed under section 2(b) as the day section 17 comes into operation.

) has.i: undertaken any counselling about the implications of the surrogacy arrangement that regulations under this Act require and

17. Requirements for surrogacy arrangeme.d: the Council is satisfied that, at least 3 months before the approval is given, each of the arranged parents, the birth mother and any donor has been assessed by a medical practitioner and confirmed, in a written report provided to the Council, to be medically suitable to be involved in the surrogacy arrangement and
17. Requirements for surrogacy arrangeme.e: the intended birth mother has not yet become pregnant under the arrangement.

20. Applying for a parentage order.(1): In the circumstances described in section 19, the arranged parents may, if the making of the order would not be prevented by section 16(1), apply in accordance with this section for a parentage order.
20. Applying for a parentage order.(2): The application can be lodged with the court only after a period of 28 days has elapsed since the day on which the child is born.
20. Applying for a parentage order.(3): The application cannot be lodged with the court more than 6 months after the day on which the child is born except with the leave of the court, which may be given in exceptional circumstances.
20. Applying for a parentage order.(4): If the child was born before the day fixed under section 2(b) as the day on which this section comes into operation, the application may, despite subsection (3), be lodged within one year after that day.
20. Applying for a parentage order.(5): Before the court considers the application, a certified copy of the childs birth certificate must, if it is available, have been lodged with the court.

21. Court may make parentage order.(1): The court may, on an application made under section 20(1), make a parentage order.

(2) Before it makes a parentage order th.a: the circumstances that section 19 requires for applying for a parentage order exist and
(2) Before it makes a parentage order th.b: except to the extent that subsection (3) authorises the court to dispense with the requirement for a birth parent to have received the counselling, the childs birth parents and the arranged parents have received appropriate counselling about the effect of the proposed order and
(2) Before it makes a parentage order th.c: except to the extent that subsection (3) authorises the court to dispense with the requirement for a birth parent to have received the advice, the childs birth parents and the arranged parents have received independent legal advice about the effect of the proposed order and
(2) Before it makes a parentage order th.d: except to the extent that subsection (3) authorises the court to dispense with the requirement for a birth parents consent, the childs birth parents freely consent to the making of the order and
(2) Before it makes a parentage order th.e: except in circumstances identified in subsection (4), the child was, when the application for the order was lodged with the court, and is, when the court makes the proposed order, in the day to day care of the arranged parents and
(2) Before it makes a parentage order th.g: it is in the best interests of the child for the court to make the proposed order.

(3) In circumstances identified in subse.a: the requirement for the birth parent to have received counselling as described in subsection (2)(b) or
(3) In circumstances identified in subse.b: the requirement for the birth parent to have received independent legal advice as described in subsection (2)(c) or
(3) In circumstances identified in subse.c: the requirement for the birth parent to consent under subsection (2)(d) to the making of a parentage order or
(3) In circumstances identified in subse.d: the requirement for the birth parent to have agreed to an appropriate plan as described in subsection (2)(f).

(4) The circumstances this subsection id.a: the birth mother is not the childs genetic parent and
(4) The circumstances this subsection id.b: at least one arranged parent is the childs genetic parent.

21. Court may make parentage order.(5) In subsection (4): genetic parent of a child means a person from whose egg or sperm the child is conceived.

(1) The plan needed to satisfy the court.a: adequately balance the rights and responsibilities of the parties to the plan and

24. Multiple births.(2): The court cannot make a parentage order about a child who has a living birth sibling unless it also makes a parentage order about each living birth sibling of the child.

25. Name of child.(1): If a parentage order is made, the court is to, by the same order, declare the name by which the child whose parentage is transferred is to be known.

(2) Before making an order changing the.a: the principle that a childs first name should not be changed by a parentage order except in special circumstances and
(2) Before making an order changing the.b: anything that is relevant in the approved plan.

25. Name of child.(3): An order under this section does not prevent a subsequent change of name under a law of the State or the Commonwealth.

(1) The effect of a parentage order is t.a: the relationship between the child whose parentage is transferred and each of the arranged parents is to be treated as being that of child and parent and
(1) The effect of a parentage order is t.b: the relationship between the child whose parentage is transferred and each of the childs birth parents is to be treated as not being that of child and parent and
(1) The effect of a parentage order is t.c: the relationships of all persons to the child whose parentage is transferred, to each of the arranged parents, and to each of the birth parents of the child are to be determined in accordance with this section.

26. Effect of parentage order.(2): If a parentage order is made, an appointment, in a deed or will existing at the time the parentage order is made, of a person as the guardian of the child whose parentage is transferred, ceases to have effect.

(1) The court may, if satisfied as descr.d: a child whose parentage was transferred by the parentage order who has reached the age of 18 years.

(2) On an application under subsection (.b: a consent relied on for the making of the parentage order was not an effective consent because it was obtained by fraud, duress or material inducement or
(2) On an application under subsection (.c: there is an exceptional reason why the parentage order should be discharged.

27. Discharge of parentage order.(3): If the court makes an order discharging a parentage order, the court is to, by the same order, declare the name by which the child whose parentage would be affected is to be known, having
27. Discharge of parentage order.(4): An order under subsection (3) does not prevent a subsequent change of name under a law of the State or the Commonwealth.

(5) The court is not to make an order un.a: to do so would be for the welfare and in the best interests of the child whose parentage would be affected and

27. Discharge of parentage order.(6): Any person may apply for leave to intervene in an application under subsection (1) and the court may make an order entitling the person to intervene in the application.
27. Discharge of parentage order.(7): A person who is permitted under subsection (6) to intervene in an application under subsection (1) is to be treated as a party to the application with all the rights, duties and liabilities of a party, unless the court orders otherwise.

(9) Where a parentage order is discharge.a: does not apply to the extent that its application would be inconsistent with any order made under subsection (8) or with section 28 and

(b) does not affect.(i) anything lawfully done or: (ii) the consequences of anything lawfully done or  (iii) any proprietary right or interest that became vested in any person,  while the parentage order was in force.

28. Relationships for laws relating to s.a: despite section 26(1) and (2), a parentage order does not cause the cessation of any relationship that would have existed if the parentage order had not been made, and any such relationship is to be treated as existing in addition to any relationship that exists by virtue of the application of this section in relation to the parentage order and
28. Relationships for laws relating to s.b: despite section 27(9), the discharge of a parentage order does not cause the cessation of any relationship that would have existed if the discharging order had not been made, and any such relationship is to be treated as existing in addition to any relationship that exists by virtue of the discharge of the parentage order.

30. Varying approved plan.(1): A person described in subsection (2) may apply to the court for approval to vary an approved plan relating to a child if the child has not reached 18 years of age.

(2) The only person who can make the app.a: a person who is a party to the approved plan or
(2) The only person who can make the app.b: a birth parent who is not a party to the approved plan.

(3) The court may approve of the plan be.a: the variation is appropriate because of a change of circumstances since the approved plan was agreed and
(3) The court may approve of the plan be.b: the plan as varied would conform to the requirements of section 22.

30. Varying approved plan.(4): The variation may be to add a new party to the plan.

33. Terms used in this Division; In this.content2: grandparent means a lineal grandparent or a lineal ancestor
33. Terms used in this Division; In this.content3: sibling means a brother or sister of the whole or half blood,  whether or not the relationship is traced through, or to, a person whose parents were not married to each other at the time of the persons birth, or subsequently.

34. Application of this Division or orde.(1): If an approved plan provides for a party to the plan to have greater or earlier access to information than would be available under this Division, the party is entitled to access in accordance with the plan.
34. Application of this Division or orde.(2): A right that this Division gives to have access to information or an order that the court makes giving access to information prevails over a provision of any contract or approved plan that purports to restrict or exclude that access.

35. Right under this Division to be trea.a: to allow the person access to the Register under that Act and
35. Right under this Division to be trea.b: to provide the person with information extracted from the Register under that Act and
35. Right under this Division to be trea.c: to search for information in the Register under that Act.

36. Court order excluding access to info.(1): On an application for a parentage order or after a parentage order has been made, a party may apply to the court for an order excluding a person from having access under this Division to information.

(2) On an application under subsection (.b: the person to whom the applicant is married, or with whom the applicant is in a de facto relationship or

36. Court order excluding access to info.(3): The order may exclude access to all or specified information in all or specified circumstances, and may exclude access from being given by the court or exclude a right of access from arising under this Division.
36. Court order excluding access to info.(4): If an order is made under subsection (2), the registrar of the court is to give the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages a certified copy of the order as soon as is practicable.
36. Court order excluding access to info.(5): On the application of a person affected by an order under subsection (2), the court may revoke, suspend, or vary the order.

37. Access to certain court records.(1): A person cannot have access to the record of proceedings in a court in relation to a parentage order except with the courts approval given on an application under subsection (2) or section 40(4) or 41(4).

42. Application of; Family Court Act 199.(2) The: Family Court Act 1997 applies as if a reference to jurisdiction of the court under that Act in section 244 referred also to jurisdiction conferred on the court by this Act.
42. Application of; Family Court Act 199.(3) In a context in which the: Family Court Act 1997 applies only because of this section, that Act applies as if a reference in that Act to a family consultant referred only to a person who is appointed in accordance with section 25 of that Act.
42. Application of; Family Court Act 199.(4) The: Family Court Act 1997 section 212 does not apply to proceedings in which the court exercises jurisdiction conferred on it by this Act.

43. Court proceedings to be private.(1) This section applies to proceedings: ) and also to any proceedings of the Supreme Court arising out of proceedings under this Part.
43. Court proceedings to be private.(2): Proceedings to which this section applies are not to be heard in open court and all persons other than a party to the proceedings or his or her lawyer are to be excluded during the proceedings, except as otherwise directed by the court.
43. Court proceedings to be private.(3): A court may order any person to leave the room or other place during the examination of a witness in the proceedings.

44. Regulations.(1): The Governor may make regulations prescribing all matters that are required or permitted by this Act to be prescribed, or are
44. Regulations.(2): Without limiting subsection (1), regulations may be made as to what is appropriate counselling for a childs birth parents and the arranged parents to receive about the effect of a proposed parentage order.

45. Review of Act.(1): The Minister shall carry out a review of the operation and effectiveness of this Act as soon as is practicable after the expiry of 4 years from its commencement.
